message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Event-Based Adaptive NN Fixed-Time Cooperative Formation for Multiagent Systems
Paper Abstract: This article focuses on the fixed-time formation control problem for nonlinear multiagent systems (MASs) with dynamic uncertainties and limited communication resources. Under the framework of the backstepping method, a time-varying formation function is introduced in the controller design. To attain the prescribed transient and steady-state performance of MASs, a fixed-time prescribed performance function (FTPPF) is designed and the further coordinate transformation addressing the zero equilibrium point problem is removed. To achieve better approximating performance, a neural network (NN)-based composite dynamic surface control (CDSC) strategy is proposed, where the CDSC scheme is consisted of prediction errors and serial-parallel estimation models. According to the signals generated by the estimation models, disturbance observers are established to overcome the difficulty from approximating errors and mismatched disturbances. Moreover, an improved dynamic event-triggered mechanism and varying threshold parameters are constructed to reduce the signal transmission frequency. Via the Lyapunov stability theory, all the signals in the closed-loop system are semi-globally uniformly ultimately bounded. Finally, the simulation results verify the effectiveness of the developed CDSC strategy.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Backstepping control"

Links: [{"title":"Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstepping"},{"title":"Strict-feedback form - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strict-feedback_form"},{"title":"Petar V. Kokotovic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petar_V._Kokotovic"},{"title":"Talk:Backstepping - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Backstepping"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Backpropagation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backpropagation"},{"title":"Backstay - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Backstay"},{"title":"Control reversal - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_reversal"},{"title":"Take back control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Take_Back_Control"},{"title":"Exponential backoff - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Exponential_backoff"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about backstepping control:

## Overview

Backstepping provides a recursive method for stabilizing the origin of a system in strict-feedback form.(no content)Backstepping is a method of taking a large and ugly nonlinear problem and stripping off all of the trivial layers so that you're left with a simpler system.

## How It Works

The single-step procedure can be completed iteratively to stabilize an entire strict-feedback system. In each step, the smallest "unstabilized" single-step strict-feedback system is isolated. Feedback is used to convert the system into a single-integrator system. The resulting single-integrator system is stabilized. The stabilized system is used as the upper system in the next step.

## Application to Nonlinear Control

Backstepping is one of several control methods, along with feedback linearization and sliding mode control, that normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory. This approach is particularly useful for controlling nonlinear systems that arise in fields like robotics and aerospace.

## Historical Contribution

Petar V. Kokotovic has made contributions in nonlinear control, especially the backstepping stabilization method.

Here are the search results for multiagent systems:

## Overview

A multi-agent system (MAS or "self-organized system") is a computerized system composed of multiple interacting intelligent agents.(no content)Multi-agent systems can solve problems that are difficult or impossible for an individual agent or a monolithic system to solve.

## Key Characteristics

Agents in multi-agent systems have important characteristics including autonomy (agents are at least partially independent, self-aware, autonomous), local views (no agent has a full global view), and decentralization (no agent is designated as controlling).

## Modern Developments

With advancements in large language models (LLMs), LLM-based multi-agent systems have emerged as a new area of research, enabling more sophisticated interactions and coordination among agents.

## Applications

Applications where multi-agent systems research may deliver an appropriate approach include online trading, disaster response, target surveillance and social structure modelling.

## Related Fields

Multi-agent reinforcement learning (MARL) is a sub-field of reinforcement learning that focuses on studying the behavior of multiple learning agents that coexist in a shared environment.

## Neural Network

I've found comprehensive information about neural networks from the search results. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Structure

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).

### Applications

Artificial neural networks are used for various tasks, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, and solving problems in artificial intelligence. More specifically, neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

### Training and Learning

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

### Historical Context

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago.(no content)In 1958, psychologist Frank Rosenblatt described the perceptron, one of the first implemented artificial neural networks, funded by the United States Office of Naval Research.

## Neural Network

I've found comprehensive information about neural networks from the search results. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Structure

A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)Signals travel from the first layer (the input layer) to the last layer (the output layer), possibly passing through multiple intermediate layers (hidden layers).

### Applications

Artificial neural networks are used for various tasks, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, and solving problems in artificial intelligence. More specifically, neural networks are used to solve problems in artificial intelligence, and have thereby found applications in many disciplines, including predictive modeling, adaptive control, facial recognition, handwriting recognition, general game playing, and generative AI.

### Training and Learning

Neural networks are typically trained through empirical risk minimization, which is based on the idea of optimizing the network's parameters to minimize the difference, or empirical risk, between the predicted output and the actual target values in a given dataset.(no content)Gradient-based methods such as backpropagation are usually used to estimate the parameters of the network.

### Historical Context

Today's deep neural networks are based on early work in statistics over 200 years ago.(no content)In 1958, psychologist Frank Rosenblatt described the perceptron, one of the first implemented artificial neural networks, funded by the United States Office of Naval Research.

Based on the search results, I found some relevant information about event-triggered control:

Event-triggered systems are a field of study where Maurice Heemels, a Full Professor at Eindhoven University of Technology, was named Fellow of the IEEE in 2016 for his contributions to analysis and design of hybrid, networked, and event-triggered systems.

While the search results didn't return a direct definition or comprehensive overview of event-triggered control specifically, the results do show that it's an established area in control theory and engineering. Event-triggered control is a control paradigm that differs from traditional time-triggered or periodic control systems. Instead of updating control actions at fixed time intervals, event-triggered control systems update their actions based on specific events or conditions occurring in the system.

The search results mainly covered related concepts like event-driven architecture, event-driven programming, and time-triggered systems, but they don't provide detailed technical information about event-triggered control theory itself. If you're looking for more specific information about event-triggered control—such as its applications, mathematical foundations, or advantages over traditional control methods—I'd recommend searching for academic papers or control theory textbooks on the subject.

Molesworth - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Percy_B._Molesworth"},{"title":"Light travel time effect - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Light_Travel_Time_Effect"},{"title":"Disturbance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Disturbance"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about disturbance observers:

## Disturbance Observer in Control Theory

A **disturbance observer** is a key component of active disturbance rejection control (ADRC), a model-free control technique used for designing controllers for systems with unknown dynamics and external disturbances.

### How It Works

The disturbance observer estimates the total disturbance (sum of unknown part of model dynamics and external disturbances) online using an extended state observer and uses it in the control signal to decouple the system from the actual perturbation acting on the plant.

An extended state observer (ESO) keeps track of the system's states as well as external disturbances and unknown model perturbations.

### Practical Benefits

The disturbance rejection feature allows users to treat the system with a simpler model, as the negative effects of modeling uncertainty are compensated in real time. ADRC does not rely on any particular mathematical model of disturbance.

### Applications

ADRC has been successfully used as an alternative to PID control in many applications, such as the control of permanent magnet synchronous motors, thermal power plants and robotics.

Web search results for query: "Control theory nonlinear"

Links: [{"title":"Nonlinear control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_control"},{"title":"Nonlinear system - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nonlinear_system"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Separation principle in stochastic control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle_in_stochastic_control"},{"title":"Model predictive control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Model_predictive_control"},{"title":"Optimal control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Sliding mode control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sliding_mode_control"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"S-procedure - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-procedure"}]

Here are the web search results for "Control theory nonlinear":

## Overview

Nonlinear control theory is the area of control theory which deals with systems that are nonlinear, time-variant, or both.(no content)Control theory is an interdisciplinary branch of engineering and mathematics that is concerned with the behavior of dynamical systems with inputs, and how to modify the output by changes in the input using feedback, feedforward, or signal filtering.

## Linear vs. Nonlinear Control

Linear control theory applies to systems made of devices which obey the superposition principle and are governed by linear differential equations. In contrast, nonlinear control theory covers a wider class of systems that do not obey the superposition principle and applies to more real-world systems, because all real control systems are nonlinear.

## Challenges and Techniques

The mathematical techniques which have been developed to handle nonlinear systems are more rigorous and much less general, often applying only to narrow categories of systems, including limit cycle theory, Poincaré maps, Lyapunov stability theory, and describing functions.(no content)Nonlinear systems are often analyzed using numerical methods on computers, for example by simulating their operation using a simulation language.

## Nonlinear Control Design Methods

Control methods such as feedback linearization, backstepping, sliding mode control, and trajectory linearization control normally take advantage of results based on Lyapunov's theory. Additionally, even if the plant is linear, a nonlinear controller can often have attractive features such as simpler implementation, faster speed, more accuracy, or reduced control energy.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Lyapunov stability theory"

Links: [{"title":"Lyapunov stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_stability"},{"title":"Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Stability theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stability_theory"},{"title":"Control-Lyapunov function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control-Lyapunov_function"},{"title":"Aleksandr Lyapunov - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aleksandr_Lyapunov"},{"title":"Lyapunov equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_equation"},{"title":"Lyapunov theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lyapunov_theorem"},{"title":"Input-to-state stability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Input-to-state_stability"},{"title":"Foster's theorem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Foster's_theorem"},{"title":"LaSalle's invariance principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/LaSalle's_invariance_principle"}]

## Lyapunov Stability Theory

Here's an overview of Lyapunov stability theory based on the search results:

### Overview

Lyapunov stability theory is used to discuss various types of stability in the solutions of differential equations or difference equations describing dynamical systems, with the most important type concerning the stability of solutions near to a point of equilibrium.

### Historical Background

Lyapunov stability is named after Aleksandr Mikhailovich Lyapunov, a Russian mathematician who defended the thesis The General Problem of Stability of Motion at Kharkov University in 1892.(no content)Lyapunov was a pioneer in developing a global approach to the analysis of the stability of nonlinear dynamical systems by comparison with the widely spread local method of linearizing them about points of equilibrium.

### Key Concepts

Near to a point of equilibrium which is Lyapunov stable, the system remains stable under small disturbances.(no content)Lyapunov stability of an equilibrium means that solutions starting "close enough" to the equilibrium remain close enough, while asymptotic stability means solutions that start close enough eventually converge to the equilibrium.

### Lyapunov Functions

Lyapunov functions are scalar functions that may be used to prove the stability of an equilibrium of an ordinary differential equation, and are important to stability theory of dynamical systems and control theory.(no content)A general way to establish Lyapunov stability or asymptotic stability of a dynamical system is by means of Lyapunov functions.

### Applications

Input-to-state stability unified the Lyapunov and input-output stability theories and revolutionized the view on stabilization of nonlinear systems, design of robust nonlinear observers, and stability of nonlinear interconnected control systems.

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of performance control systems:

## General Concept

A control system manages, commands, directs, or regulates the behavior of other devices or systems using control loops, ranging from a single home heating controller using a thermostat controlling a domestic boiler to large industrial control systems which are used for controlling processes or machines.

## Management Control Systems

In an organizational context, management control systems are tools to aid management for steering an organization toward its strategic objectives and competitive advantage.(no content)Management control is concerned with coordination, resource allocation, motivation, and performance measurement.(no content)A management control system should include a comprehensive set of performance aspects consisting of both financial and non-financial metrics.

## Technical Control Systems

The practice uses sensors and detectors to measure the output performance of the process being controlled; these measurements are used to provide corrective feedback helping to achieve the desired performance.(no content)Control systems that include some sensing of the results they are trying to achieve are making use of feedback and can adapt to varying circumstances to some extent.

## Types of Control

Open-loop control systems do not make use of feedback, and run only in pre-arranged ways. In contrast, closed-loop systems use feedback to continuously monitor and adjust performance against desired targets.

Performance control systems are fundamental across many domains, from industrial automation to organizational management to automotive systems.

Web search results for query: "State observer control"

Links: [{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Active disturbance rejection control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_disturbance_rejection_control"},{"title":"United Nations General Assembly observers - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_Nations_General_Assembly_observers"},{"title":"Observability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observability"},{"title":"Observer pattern - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_pattern?amp=&amp="},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"},{"title":"Talk:State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:State_observer"},{"title":"Separation principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Separation_principle"},{"title":"Observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer"},{"title":"Observer status - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Observer_status"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about state observer control:

## State Observer in Control Theory

In control theory, a state observer, state estimator, or Luenberger observer is a system that provides an estimate of the internal state of a given real system, from measurements of the input and output of the real system.(no content)It is typically computer-implemented, and provides the basis of many practical applications.

### Key Applications and Purpose

Knowing the system state is necessary to solve many control theory problems; for example, stabilizing a system using state feedback.(no content)In most practical cases, the physical state of the system cannot be determined by direct observation. Instead, indirect effects of the internal state are observed by way of the system outputs.

A practical example is provided: vehicles in a tunnel: the rates and velocities at which vehicles enter and leave the tunnel can be observed directly, but the exact state inside the tunnel can only be estimated.

### Observer Types

Linear, delayed, sliding mode, high gain, Tau, homogeneity-based, extended and cubic observers are among several observer structures used for state estimation of linear and nonlinear systems.

### Connection to System Observability

If a system is observable, it is possible to fully reconstruct the system state from its output measurements using the state observer.

I've completed the web search for "Robotic systems control" and retrieved relevant information. Here's a summary of what was found:

## Key Findings:

**Definition and Basics:**
Robotic control is the system that contributes to the movement of robots and involves the mechanical aspects and programmable systems that make it possible to control robots.

**Control Methods:**
Robotics can be controlled by various means including manual, wireless, and semi-autonomous methods. Additionally, artificial intelligence (AI) is used in robotic control to make it able to process and adapt to its surroundings.

**Modern Control Systems:**
Robotics engineers design control algorithms that manage the interaction between sensors, actuators, and software, and most robots rely on closed-loop control systems, where sensors provide continuous feedback to adjust movements and behaviors.

**Motion Control Components:**
The main components involved in motion control typically include a motion controller, an energy amplifier, and one or more prime movers or actuators.

**Advanced Technologies:**
Software engineering is a fundamental aspect of robotics, focusing on the development of code and systems that control a robot's hardware and manage real-time decision-making, and robotics software encompasses both low-level control software and high-level applications.

The search revealed comprehensive information about robotic systems control from industrial applications to autonomous systems used in space exploration and research.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [in_progress] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

| Neural network (machine learning) | method | proposes | Novel NN-based composite dynamic surface control strategy |
| Lyapunov stability | concept | uses | Used for stability analysis and proof of system boundedness |
| State observer | method | proposes | Novel disturbance observers and estimation models proposed |
| Active disturbance rejection control | method | uses | Related technique for handling disturbances and uncertainties |
| Control theory | concept | uses | Foundational framework for all design and analysis |

| Control system | concept | uses | Core concept of feedback control systems in the paper |
